titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid of the Dave Berkman Papers, 1958-2016
titlestmt.author: Christel Maass

publicationstmt.publisher: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries, Archives Department
publicationstmt.date: Copyright © 2016 University of Wisconsin Board of Regents

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Christel Maass.

physdesc.label: Quantity
physdesc.extent: 3.4 cubic ft. (5 boxes, including 38 audio cassettes)

extref.corpname: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries, Archives Department

did.abstract: Papers of former UWM professor and media critic Dave Berkman consisting of articles, including copies of his Shepherd Express "Media Musings," news clippings, correspondence, and an extensive set of radio broadcasts, largely Wisconsin Public Radio recordings.

bioghist.p: Dave Berkman (1934-2015) was a college professor and media critic. Berkman taught mass communications at UW-Milwaukee, among other universities. For many years he wrote a column called "Media Musings" for the Shepherd Express, a Milwaukee alternative paper. He also hosted Wisconsin Public Radio's "Media Talk" show for 13 years.

Berkman was a liberal, a civil rights activist, and a free speech absolutist, and served on the state boards of the ACLU in Wisconsin and Connecticut, as well as on the Corporation for Public Broadcasting's Minority Task Force. Berkman was a member of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters, and advocated protecting Public Broadcasting's independence from political threats. He was a man of strong opinions who loved politics and argument.

scopecontent.p: The paper files largely consist of correspondence, copies of Berkman's "Media Musings" in Milwaukee's Shepherd Express alternative newspaper, publications and articles, and clipping files. The collection also includes Berkman's 1963 dissertation, as well as various reports, including information about the work of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting's Minority Task Force on which Berkman served.

The radio broadcasts, largely Wisconsin Public Radio recordings, cover a wide variety of local and national topics, many of which concern meta-analysis of media coverage of events. Most of the electronic recordings in the collection are of Berkman's Media Talk show on Wisconsin Public Radio (2003-2006), which took a weekly look at how issues such as Global Warming, Hurricane Katrina, the 2003 Iraq War, the 2004 presidential election, and the Judith Miller/Scooter Libby intelligence disclosure scandal were covered by national and Wisconsin media. Berkman also frequently guest-hosted for fellow WPR correspondents Eric Vonn, Joy Cardin, and Ben Merens; as befitting Berkman's speciality, most of these shows also dealt with media and political issues, such as the makeup of the African-American Vote, the Wisconsin Primary's effect on Super Tuesday 2004, and U.S. Energy policy. Both of these shows often featured prominent guests from the media and political worlds, including Kathleen Parker, Terry Neal, Eugene Kane, James Wolcott, and Chris Bowers, as well as local Wisconsin journalists and activists such as Tim Cuprisin, Bill Lueders, Craig Gilbert, Mordecai Lee, and Stan Stojkovic. A small number of electronic recordings are of shows on which Berkman appeared as a guest himself, mostly as part of a weekly media panel on the Eric Vonn show.

The audio cassettes mainly consist of Media Talk broadcasts. There are several cassettes that consist of shows that Berkman hosted and Berkman being a guest on the Kathleen Dunn Show and the Ben Merens Show. Topics discussed on the shows include the Jesse Anderson case, Jeffrey Dahmer case, Laurie Bembenek, Second Amendment, media influence on society, quality of journalism, labor union issues, and politics.
The videocassette consists of an episode of the show Conservative Forum. As the guest on the show, Berkman discussed his views on the United States' military presence in the world.

arrangement.p: The files are arranged into the following series:

otherfindaid.p: A spreadsheet with detailed information about the electronic recordings is available in the Archives. The spreadsheet includes information about the show for which the recordings were made, the title/topic of the show, the featured guests, the date of broadcast, and the approximate duration of the recording. Additional technical metadata is available in the Archives; consult an archivist for more details.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material in the UWM Libraries

accessrestrict.p: There are no access restrictions on the materials, and the collection is open to all members of the public in accordance with state law.

userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of libel, privacy, and copyright which may be involved in the use of this collection (Wisconsin Statutes 19.21-19.39).

acqinfo.p: Margarita Dusek donated the collection to the Archives in September and November 2016 (accession 2016-015).

processinfo.p: Christel Maass minimally processed the paper records in September 2016 and November 2016. Phyllis Reske processed the audio cassettes and videocassettes, and Brad Houston and Phyllis Reske processed the electronic records in October and November 2016.

processinfo.head: Preservation Information
processinfo.p: During November 2016, Electronic records were transferred from CD-ROMs to the Archives Department Server. In cases where MP3 files were not immediately accessible for reasons of format, FTK Imager was used to extract the files and convert them to a format readable on Windows. The CDs will be maintained as backups and reevaluated for playability in 2008.

phystech.p: As of November 22, 2016, all electronic files were accessible on a Intel Core i5-4570 CPU (3.20 GHz, 4 GB RAM) running Windows 7 Enterprise, with Service Pack 1. Windows Media Player was used to access the files.
The collection includes records in the following formats:

physdesc.extent: 4.2 cubic ft. (5 boxes, including 38 audio cassettes)

did.unittitle: Corporation for Public Broadcasting's Minority Task Force, 1978-1981

arrangement.p: The recordings in each subseries are arranged chronologically by date of broadcast. Audio numbers under recordings signify physical audio cassettes; "ID No." under recordings signifies digital files accessible in the Archives. See an archivist for more information.
